parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The post does not contain a CMF number. While the absence of a CMF number is not automatically disqualifying, it suggests the post might not be directly linked to official electoral campaign materials.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post mentions UDMR (Uniunea Democrată Maghiară din România), a political party participating in the parliamentary elections.  However, it does not explicitly refer to a specific candidate by name or surname. The hashtag #alegevocearațiunii translates to "choose your voice of reason" and is a general call to action, not a direct endorsement of a specific candidate.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform.  The message is clearly intended to reach a wide audience, not just a specific individual or small group. The use of hashtags further suggests an attempt to reach a broader audience.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The post promotes a vision for education reform ("Vrem un stat în care școala înseamnă educație reală și aplicată, un loc fără pariuri, droguri și bullying"). While this is a topic relevant to political discourse and could indirectly influence voters' choices, the primary objective does not appear to be directly influencing votes for a specific candidate or party. The call to action ("#alegevocearațiunii") is general and doesn't explicitly urge voters to support UDMR.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post could be considered a form of political communication aiming to present the UDMR's stance on education. However, it lacks the objectivity and factual reporting typically associated with journalism. It presents a specific viewpoint rather than offering balanced information.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The post doesn't express a personal opinion; it presents a political party's platform on a specific issue.  While it's not strictly journalistic, it's not necessarily direct electoral propaganda either.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>2099866653743220</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post promotes a political party's (UDMR) position on education reform. While this is related to the political landscape and could indirectly influence voters, it doesn't directly advocate for a specific candidate or explicitly urge voters to support UDMR. The absence of a CMF number and the general nature of the call to action weaken the argument for it being direct electoral propaganda.  The post's focus on a policy issue, rather than direct candidate endorsement, is a key factor.  While the line between advocacy and propaganda can be blurry, in this case, the evidence doesn't strongly suggest a violation.
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates>
</electoral-propaganda-candidates>
<responsible-party-or-group>UDMR</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police>
</message-for-police>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
